Reproducible R Development with Docker and renv

Docker
R
Reproducibility
renv
DevOps
A guide to setting up reproducible R development environments using Docker and renv for team collaboration.
Author

phb 243b

Published

December 8, 2025

1 Introduction

Ensuring reproducibility in R Markdown can be challenging. Package version mismatches and OS differences cause issues. The solution: renv (package management) + Docker (containerization).

2 Workflow Overview

This guide demonstrates a two-developer workflow:

  • Developer 1: Sets up renv & Docker, pushes to GitHub & DockerHub.
  • Developer 2: Clones repo, pulls Docker image, runs & modifies analysis.
  • Uses bind mounting to ensure local files persist and are accessible outside the container.

3 Developer 1: Initial Setup

3.1 Step 1: Setup GitHub Repository

Start by creating a new repository for your project:

git clone https://github.com/username/penguins-analysis.git
cd penguins-analysis

3.2 Step 2: Initialize renv

Initialize renv to manage package versions:

install.packages("renv")
renv::init()

This creates renv.lock to track package versions consistently across all collaborators.

3.3 Step 3: Install Required Packages

Install your project dependencies and snapshot them:

install.packages("ggplot2")
install.packages("palmerpenguins")
renv::snapshot()

The renv::snapshot() command saves exact package versions to renv.lock.

3.4 Step 4: Create Dockerfile

Create a reproducible Docker environment:

FROM rocker/r-ver:4.1.0
WORKDIR /workspace
RUN R -e "install.packages('renv', repos='https://cloud.r-project.org')"
COPY renv.lock renv/activate.R /workspace/
RUN R -e "renv::restore()"
CMD ["/bin/bash"]

Note: This Dockerfile does NOT include analysis files like peng1.Rmd - those are handled locally by collaborators using bind mounting.

3.5 Step 5: Build & Push Docker Image

Build and publish your Docker image:

docker build -t username/penguins-analysis:v1 .
docker login
docker push username/penguins-analysis:v1

Your image is now available on DockerHub for team members.

3.6 Step 6: Push to GitHub

Commit and push your configuration:

git add .
git commit -m "Initial renv setup and Docker environment (without Rmd)"
git push origin main

4 Developer 2: Working with the Setup

4.1 Step 1: Clone Repository & Pull Docker Image

Get the repository and Docker image locally:

git clone https://github.com/username/penguins-analysis.git
cd penguins-analysis
docker pull username/penguins-analysis:v1

4.2 Step 2: Run Docker with Bind Mounting

Run the Docker container with your local directory mounted:

docker run --rm -it -v "$(pwd):/workspace" -w /workspace username/penguins-analysis:v1 /bin/bash

This command: - -v "$(pwd):/workspace": Mounts your local repository to /workspace in the container - Allows you to edit files locally while running code in the reproducible environment

4.3 Step 3: Create Analysis File

Write your analysis as peng1.Rmd inside the container:

---
title: "Palmer Penguins Analysis"
author: "Developer 2"
date: "2025-12-08"
output: html_document
---

\`\`\`{r}
library(ggplot2)
library(palmerpenguins)

# Explicitly use palmerpenguins::penguins to avoid conflicts
ggplot(palmerpenguins::penguins, aes(x = flipper_length_mm, y = bill_length_mm)) +
  geom_point() + theme_minimal()
\`\`\`

4.4 Step 4: Render Your Analysis

Generate the HTML output:

rmarkdown::render("peng1.Rmd")

The output peng1.html is saved locally thanks to the bind mount, accessible outside the container.

4.5 Step 5: Extend & Share

Add more analysis and push back to GitHub:

## Body Mass vs. Bill Length

\`\`\`{r}
ggplot(palmerpenguins::penguins, aes(x = body_mass_g, y = bill_length_mm)) +
  geom_point() + theme_minimal()
\`\`\`

Then commit and push:

git add peng1.Rmd
git commit -m "Added second plot: Body Mass vs. Bill Length"
git push origin main

5 Key Benefits

  • ✅ renv ensures package reproducibility across team members
  • ✅ Docker ensures OS and R version consistency
  • ✅ GitHub and DockerHub enable seamless collaboration
  • ✅ Bind mounting ensures local modifications persist outside containers
  • ✅ Each developer maintains local control while ensuring reproducibility

6 Conclusion

This workflow combines three powerful tools to create truly reproducible R development environments that teams can share and extend. By using renv for package management, Docker for environment consistency, and GitHub for version control, you enable robust collaboration on data science projects.
